content: I feel like https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/76976 is going in circles with "borrowing [as opposed to copying] the bytes of an integer is useful because it lets me borrow the bytes of an integer"
&mut is more interesting for in-place modification, but even that is hampered by needing endian-awareness in whatever you pass that to.
why is in-place modification of individual bytes more useful than in-place modification by assigning the result of from_ne_bytes to the entire &mut f64 ?
it's not particularly, but also this can be handled flawlessly by crates that already exist today, and it will also be handled by the safe-transmute project.
